text:
The United States has the
highest health care spending
per capita in the world.

It accounts for
almost 20% of our GDP,

but life expectancy
improvements in the US

have fallen far short
of poor nations.

Why does the US with
significantly higher

expenditure produce
worse outcomes?

There are a number of factors
that make our health care

system so costly
and inefficient,

such as rapidly growing
administrative costs, high drug

prices with limited
transparency, an aging

population, and a growing
number of uninsured individuals.

With such a wildly complex
system and an emphasis

on maintaining high
profit margins,

how can we hope to
drive change that

will make our lives
better and our health care
system more equitable?

That is the question the next
generation of health care

professionals will
need to answer.

It may not be an easy answer,
but it is necessary and urgent,

and it requires
exceptional leadership.

The Health Care
Initiative's mission

is to educate the
leaders of tomorrow

who will innovate, inspire, and
improve health care for all.
